But when it comes to riots and violence in the squares of Italy, the Fascists have
been the greater offenders against law and order and public security in the l?ast few years
— and I underscore the last few years# In early postwar years, the Comunists prove iked
riots and lawless demonstr? lions almost on a regular schedule# But in recent years, the
Communists have been following, most of the time, the so-called "soft* line of Palmiro
Togliatti# They have generally shunned violence in the squares in their effort to seem
respectable enough to attract middle class voters# And generally, when the interior minis¬
try’s "celere," or jeep-equipped flying squads, have been called out in the last few years,
it has been to cope with activities of the neo-Fascists#
Although Fascist activites are prohibited by law, the government until now has not
taken these demonstrations too seriously# It felt th t it might be unwise to make too much
over thamj that government action might be exactly what the Fascists wanted, exactly what
they could exploit best, in e, propaganda way*
And anyhow, observers of these affairs generally felt that they were not the old
Fascist-type demonstrations of the 1920b, but rather the loosely-organised exhibitions of
young publicity-seekers*
This last episode was quite another matter# For the first time, some Italians who had
taken neo-Faseism lightly, admitted that it reminded tk$m very much of the 1920s# For it
was a semi-military squad of 60-odd young men in uniform that carried out the asemilt
against Communist headquarters# The police investigation established beyond doubt that the
affair was well-planned in advance, and executed according to orders — except, of course,
for the explosion that blew off a part of young Oionfrida’s arm#
Now even though a Fascist party is illegal, under Italian law, it almost certainly
would be useless to attempt to put the MSI out of business in the oourts# If Fascism is an
idea, or, as I put it earlier, a state of mind, it cannot be legislated or prosecuted out of
existence no matter how strict the law# And anyhow, any such action would be stoutly
opposed by many Italians who have no sympathy for Fascism# They would feel it hypocritical
to outlaw the MSI while taking no action against a Communist party that they are convinced
is actually an instrument of Soviet Hussian foreign policy#
But another Italian law prohibiting private military, or quasi-military, organisation®
seems to make much more sense*
And a good many thoughtful Italians are asking why the government should not enforce
this law to the hilt against the organisation that carried out the recent incident# For
the fact is that the existence of such a Fascist organization has been no mystery for many
weeks# As I indicated earlier, its members made an open appearance during the funeral
ceremonies for Marshal Graziani, dressed in their grey-green blouses, black ties, and
carrying fascist trappings# And on that occasion, tinder specific instructions from the
Fascist party, posted openly all over Horae, these would-be stoxm troopers raised their arms
in the familiar Fascist salute, as the funeral procession passed#
One of Italy’s moat res onsible journalists says this new Fascist militia has taken
the name, "Guard of the Labara," meaning the guard of the old Homan military standard, which
the Fascists used as a trapping# And this journalist says, ominously, that the new
organization is little different from the old Fascist militia in its early days#
There is no doubt, incidentally, that the Communists, too, have such a quasi-military
organization, commanded by their guerrilla warfare expert, Luigi Longo# But government
police and carabinieri hare harrassed the Communist organization at every opportunity, and
have, in fact, captured a great many of its hidden stores of arms*
